title: 111_s2983
content: The "Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010" allows for payroll tax forgiveness for hiring unemployed workers. The "Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010" provides a special exemption for certain individuals hired in 2010, where wages paid by a qualified employer are exempt from taxes for services performed during that year. A qualified employer is defined as any employer other than the United States, any State, any local government, or any instrumentality of the foregoing. For the "Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010," a qualified employer is any employer except the United States, States, local governments, or their instrumentalities. A qualified individual must start employment between February 3, 2010, and January 1, 2011, certify limited prior employment, not replace another employee unless voluntarily or for cause, and not fall under specific criteria. The "Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010" allows qualified employers to hire individuals between February 3, 2010, and January 1, 2011, under specific conditions. Employers must certify limited prior employment, not replace employees unless voluntarily or for cause, and may elect to not have certain subsections apply. Additionally, wages paid to qualified individuals by qualified employers may be excluded from payroll taxes for a 1-year period. The amendments made by the "Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010" apply to wages paid after the date of the enactment of the Act. Amounts equal to the reduction in revenues to the Treasury by the amendments are appropriated to the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Trust Fund and the Federal Disability Insurance Trust Fund. SEC. 3. Business credit for retention of certain newly hired individuals in 2010. The current year business credit under section 38(b) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 will be increased by $1,000 for each retained worker who meets specific criteria. A retained worker is defined as a qualified individual employed by the taxpayer for at least 52 consecutive weeks, with wages in the last 26 weeks equaling at least 80% of the first 26 weeks.
